p: The bioactivity-guided screening of the stem bark of Polyalthia oliveri (Annonaceae) led Kouam et al. to isolate two indolosesquiterpene alkaloids, named N-acetyl-8α-polyveolinone ( 16) and N-acetyl-polyveoline ( 17) (Fig. 5) [ 64]. This species is used in folk medicine for the treatment of malaria [ 75]. Both compounds were tested against CQ-sensitive NF54 strain and compound 16 showed moderate antiplasmodial activity with IC 50 = 7.6 μM, while compound 17 inhibited the strain weakly with an IC 50 value of 29.1 μM [ 75].
